title: Deputy Chief Constable reacts to HMIC report | Border
text:
Cumbria Police Credit: ITV Border Deputy Chief Constable Michelle Skeer has responded to a recent report from HMIC that describes Cumbria Constabulary as "well prepared to face its future financial challenges" .
DCC Skeer claims the recent proposals for further cuts will have a "detrimental effect on what the HMIC recognises as a good and efficient force":
The reports reflects the hard work that has gone into making the savings to date that have been required of us, through managing change effectively and implementing new ways of working – such as the Command and Control Room, and new technology that allows our officers to work out and about in the community more. These changes have involved a lot of difficult decisions and our officers and staff have had to adjust to a lot of change over a relatively short period of time, while continuing to provide a professional policing service for the people of Cumbria.
The report states that the Constabulary is ‘well prepared to face its future financial challenges’. However the recent proposals for further cuts, of potentially £26 million, would have a detrimental effect on what the HMIC recognises as a good and efficient force.
We have worked tirelessly to ensure previous savings would not result in losing our connections to local communities and issues. If the proposed future cuts are approved, this would no longer be the case and the level of service we would be able to provide would be unrecognisable to people currently living in Cumbria.
– Deputy Chief Constable Michelle Skeer Last updated Tue 20 Oct 2015 Read more 8 updates Cumbria Police faces funding cuts of up to £26m Politics Cumbria
